title: Spark Plugs - Inspection

body.body: Assessing the condition of a spark plug can be a valuable aid to a technician, and a good source of information about the engines overall operating condition.
In general, a light brown/grey colour tells you that the spark plug is operating at optimum temperature and that the engine is in good condition.
Dark colouring, such as heavy wet or dry deposits, can indicate:
too cold a heat range spark plug
too large a spark plug gap.
If the deposits are wet, it can be an indication of:
poor oil control from the piston rings
an extremely rich condition - depending on the actual liquid present at the firing tip.
Signs of fouling or excessive heat must be traced quickly to prevent further deterioration of performance and possible engine damage.

An engines condition can be judged by the appearance of the spark plugs firing end. If the firing end of a spark plug is light brown or grey, the condition can be judged to be good and the spark plug is functioning optimally.

Although there are many different scenarios, if the insulation resistance between the centre electrode and the shell is over 10 Ohms, the engine can be started normally. If the insulation resistance drops to 0 Ohms, the firing end is fouled by either wet or dry carbon.
When a spark plug overheats, deposits that have accumulated on the insulator tip melt and give the insulator a glazed or glossy appearance.
The accumulation of deposits on the firing end is influenced by oil leakage, fuel quality and the engines operating duration.
Breakage is usually caused by thermal expansion and thermal shock due to sudden heating or cooling.

Melting is caused by overheating. Mostly, the electrode surface is rather lustrous and uneven. The melting point of nickel alloy is 1200 to 1300 째C (2200 to 2400 째F).
